content.body: Now that we have the ability to generate a copy of the spec with static annotations, I wonder what it would take to combine that with the dynamic annotations in the WHATWG copy so that the script only needs to check for changes in the annotations since the last commit
that would significantly reduce load time on the spec
it would actually increase load time for the spec itself
the bottle neck is the javascript performance, not the download time
on another note, maybe we should have people pass a test to prove that they have read the html5 spec before they're allowed to propose text- or process- level changes to the spec or wg.
Lachy: in your browser maybe :-)
Lachy: in safari, the JS runs nice and fast
crap i marked the last checkin editorial but it affected html5 parser implementations
I don't like using safari for reading the spec because it lacks essential features I need for reading it efficiently
Hixie: that would seriously cut down on the number of proposals, if enforced
Hixie: What kind of test, given that people are unlikely to retain even a small part of the whole spec?
Dashiva: open book
Lachy: like what?
wonders what he's missing!
So more like a "Read these sections" in practice then :)
like Find As You Type
without having to press cmd+F or '/' to start searching
Dashiva: no, there are plenty of questions that require a clear understanding of many partso of the spec to answer.
only Firefox has that feature. My repeated attempts to convince people that we need it Opera have failed :-(
and Safari's find feature has an unacceptable delay
Lachy: putting a finger on a single key is too much?
I find it more than acceptable in return for being able to have single key shortcuts
Dashiva, I hate single key shortcuts, and yes, being forced to press a single key I never remember to press is annoying
Hixie, if I find some time this weekend, I'll see if I can take a look at the annotations script and merge it with the static version
cool
Hixie, how does status.cgi work? Is it backed by a database or static files?
backed by mysql
would it be possible to get a copy of that database, status.cgi and any other files used for the annotations?
last time I tried to do anything with the annotations script, my attempts failed because I couldn't substitue status.cgi with static files and so the script wouldn't run properly
oh, maybe I don't need to. I can just set up a local server side script that passes off all requests for status.cgi to your copy, thus bypassing the cross-origin restrictions
http://damowmow.com/temp/status.tar.gz
thanks
can anyone remember why we block manifests to only contain URLs with the same scheme?
sorry about all the public-html spam
I was just following orders
I was just about to say
you dominate my inbox
i like how manu decided that microdata -- which was introduced 3 months ago -- was controversial under his 4 month rule
but let it not be suggested that he's just doing this because he wants to bring attention to rdfa!
annevk42: DanC and rubys very specifically asked me to send a fresh email per issue
Hixie: that's why I asked him for citatations...
I like how he didn't want to change his draft in the middle of the poll until it started looking like he was going to lose
<object> loading code look "fun"
*looks
feedback so far on charsets

giving Windows-31J a Windows-932 alias can be done, giving encodings an alias that starts with "x-" cannot be done and registering treating things such as ISO-8859-1 -> windows-1252 is considered unwise
annevk42: why unwise?
annevk42: I can understand the x- stuff on the level of principle but not on the level of usefulness
not sure, I asked some follow-up questions
this is the feedback in email form: http://mail.apps.ietf.org/ietf/charsets/msg01833.html
are people document.writing their flash objects in order to get around some Eolas-non-infringement silliness in IE?
or do people just love to document.write stuff?
hsivonen: Most offline applications do treat ISO-8859-1 as ISO-8859-1
mumbles about *Internet* Assigned Name Authority vs. "offline"

hsivonen, yeah, the Eolas patent is a large part of the reason, and even though Microsoft have, I think, since entered into a licencing agreement, that problem doesn't exists as much. However, Opera still suffers from the issue cause we don't pay the licencing fees
Lachy_: Opera has code for working around Eolas?
gsnedders|work: I can see how it would suck if Java or Python APIs magically changed their meaning of ISO-8859-1 suddenly
it would still be good to have a Web-aware new decoder getter
hsivonen: Surely that's the inevitable result of getting them defined as aliases, though?
hsivonen, AIUI, we implement the same document.write workaround that IE did
Lachy_: I see. That's news to me.
but for flash embeded without document.write, we still require the click to activate nonsense
Missing logs for 11th and 12th fixed, thanks Lachy_
oh noes! all the secret cabal talk leaked. :-)
krijnh: thanks!
Indeed :)
I've only stripped some quit/join messages
krijnh, there may still be some missing. I think there were a few hours during which I wasn't connected
Did you strip the bit where you admitted you were going to strip some secret discussions and then strip your admission and then deny all knowledge of it?
Yeah
But who cares
so if someone wants to fill in those hours between around midnight and 08:00, give or take a few hours, feel free to do so
Philip`: I already said that two minutes ago, see the logs
And in the meantime, don't flag any lines

I don't need them, do you think others do?
iurro

krijnh, you need a UPS

I like being missed :>
hugs krijnh

I you thought Dean Edwards hosting his stuff from his kitchen was weird, you should come take a look at my configuration :)

And thanks for the hugs gsnedders|work!
encodings are such a mess
krijnh: You should build yourself a datacenter

logs IRC on a (fairly) stable server, but has no way of viewing the logs other than cat
Redundancy is they key on such mission-crtitical applications
jgraham: it's already producing smoke when Sam posts some links to it from his site :)
krijnh: Sounds like you need caching :-)
krijnh: Oh the /. suggestion was just to increase your downtime and/or set fire to your house
That's three times 'you need' I don't really agree with :)
Let's just not make HTML 5 a failure, so people don't need the logs anymore in a few years, okay?
krijnh, you really need things you don't agree with
krijnh: Also, you need to transfer the entire contents of your bank account to me

krijnh: I suggest you get a bank with a large overdraft, remove all the money to the overdraft limit as cash and then transfer the remaining debt to Philip`
I'm afraid that's missing the point :-(
looks like I can run a persistent process on my server, like IRC. I just need to find out what software to use to do it
irssi!
krijnh, could I get a copy of your logging software, so I can set up a mirror?
hmm, krijnh is just hosting his IRC logs
annevk42, yeah, but he has some nice scripts that format it as HTML that I don't want to rewrite if I don't have to
Lachy: the logging software is just mIRC
You don't want to receive my crappy scripts either :)
Or put differently, I don't want to share my crappy scripts with the outside world, cause then nobody will ever take me serious anymore
Self-handicapping ftw
fine. I will have to find or write my own alternative.
for now, I will try to figure out how I can install irissi on my server
"apt-get install irssi"
then run it in screen
then configure it a tiny bit
I have no experience using screen. How does that work?
the apt-get command is not available
Substitute the appropriate package manager for your Linux distro
But I plan on rewriting some stuff
And using Bens suggestions for styling as well

You type "screen", and it runs a shell, and you run stuff in there; then you can press ctrl+A D to detach the screen, and "screen -r" to reattach to it later (possibly from a totally new ssh session or whatever)
you'll want to add -U to those to force UTF-8 sanity
unless your copy of screen is configured to be sane-by-default
Philip`, I have no idea what linux distro is being used
It seems to work for me without -U, with some combination of LANG=something.UTF-8 (both outside and inside screen) and suitable irssi configuration
Lachy: Try 'cat /etc/lsb-release' perhaps
# screen
Cannot access '/dev/pts/1': No such file or directory
# cat /etc/lsb-release
cat: /etc/lsb-release: No such file or directory
Lachy: if you are on dreamhost it's debian and there's a pre built irssi on the web somewhere
Do you have root access to the server, or is it a silly share hosting thing?
beowulf, no, this is asmallorange.com
*shared
it's a shared hosting thing
so i might be out of luck
Oh, package managers won't work then
and you'd have to install stuff manually
Does 'gcc' exist on there?

That would solve a lot
krijnh: I guess it can, if you set it to use a network drive
True
(which could be attached to Samba on a real OS)

gcc is there
Ah, so it's not totally hopeless
If irssi isn't already installed you could probably just do ./configure && make to set it up without much pain

You might be a bit stuck if screen doesn't work because it can't access the /dev stuff, though
Dreamhost TOC forbid IRC clients/bots

they are frowned upon, not forbidden, afaik

http://wiki.dreamhost.com/KB_/_Unix_/_Cron_Jobs_and_Persistent_Processes#What_is_your_persistent_.28background.29_process_policy.3F
could in principle run it but isn't actually going to
"IRC-related persistent processes of any kind (including, but not limited to, bots, bouncers, etc.) are STRICTLY PROHIBITED, and are in violation of our TOS. "
not such a Dream after all :-(
http://wiki.dreamhost.com/Irssi

jgraham: Why what?

jgraham: Because everyone who wants to check it out would have to download the 6GB repository, instead of the ~300MB subtree revision that they're usually interested in
Philip`: http://git.or.cz/gitwiki/SubprojectSupport
Sounds like it solves that problem
Unless I misunderstood the problem
Why have everything in one repo is nobody cares about parts of it normally?
hsivonen, RDF has brought us a great many wonderful thing
s
(I assume the problem is roughly "there is a whole load of artwork which people don't need to check out often and source code that they do")
"This implementation has not been completed due to these problems. A newer implementation is in the works ..." - doesn't sound like the problem is actually solved
Oh well I heard that Git had soloved these problems. Maybe the new thing is fixed
(and it certainly wasn't solved several years ago when we started using SVN)
(and migration would be a pain, even if it the new system was better)

jgraham: It's approximately that problem, although there's some artwork which people do check out (in order to run the game) and lot more which they don't (which is mostly source material for artists, and isn't publicly visible at all because its copyright status is often questionable)
wonders what game

Also there's lots of versions of precompiled executables in SVN, which is fine in SVN because everyone just downloads the latest revision and it's got everything they need to run the game, and we wouldn't want to use a DVCS where everyone has to download all historic revisions of those files too
(and if we don't include the executables in the VCS then it's more of a pain for anyone who wants to run it)

WCAG 2 that is

the entire premise here is that the minutes aren't really equivalent to the audio data

hmm, old guard doesn't want recordings :/

Not to mention that it expands the scope of people to whom explainations are avaliable

Hixie: want to clarify something about workers and cross-origin requests: As I read the current spec, the behavior is simple: workers can only be created from same-origin resources, importScript() allows cross origin resources.
is that correect?
(I got confused by some older messages I saw on the list that indicated it was more subtle)
aboodman: Yep.  importscript is support to be like <script> iirc
hmm, html4all.org's dns registration expired

aboodman_mac: Yes.
Ok. I don't think we have test coverage for this in webkit.
i will make a patch.
aboodman_mac: Possibly not.
aboodman_mac: thx.
annevk42: the fact that an accessibility "expert" refuses to discuss accessibility in an accessible medium is ENTIRELY YOUR FAULT
(c.f. http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2009Aug/0747.html )
facepalms
wonders if any HTML WG members would actually require transcriptions of audio
at the risk of agreeing with john foliot, that's really beside the point
even if we ignore deaf people, there are hearing impaired and hard of hearing people who could have trouble keeping up with a live telephone conversation
even if we ignore those people, there are people whose shaky command of the english language would preclude them from keeping up with a live telephone conversation
even if we ignore those people, there are people who would be asleep during the live telephone conversation, regardless of when it was held
I thought the issue was audio recordings, which aren't live
even if we ignore those people, there are people who were sick yesterday (cough me cough) and were in no condition to attend a live telephone conversation
(Transcriptions would certainly be more useful regardless of accessibility, because you can skim-read and copy-and-paste etc)
even if we ignore those people, there are people who would like to be able to read, search, copy-and-paste, and generally interact with written text
jinx

anyway, it boggles my mind that the w3c charges companies a million dollars a year to participate, insists on weekly teleconferences, puts people in leadership positions who use their position to harass people into attending those teleconferences, then says they don't have the money to transcribe the teleconference
Surely you aren't claiming the w3c is inaccessible?
as far as i know, the WHATWG has never held a teleconference
Sorry, forgot my </sarcasm>
never insisted that people attend a teleconference

apparently, the w3c has a policy -- and we all know how much work goes into their policies -- that inaccessible mediums are fine as long as you don't share them

Is there anyway to get the html parser to create an element in no namespace?
gsnedders: No
Why would you want that?
jgraham: Because html5lib has code for that case
jgraham: And using a conforming DOM Level 3 Core impl causes the DOM impl to break
Is it possible to create with any namespace that's no html, svg or mathml?
Dashiva, only via createElementNS()
jgraham: As it creates element in no namespace using createElement(), and that means localName, prefix, and namespaceURI are None
gsnedders: Oh well html5lib will, eventually, allow you to put html elements in no namespace thater than in the HTML namespace
At the moment it ought to put everything into a namespace
(I get around 800 failures due to this bug)
It doesn't.
jgraham, why will it allow you to put html elements in no namespace?
DOM is badly broken
Lachy: Because for non-browser cases there is really no good reason to pay the namespace tax in the common case
fair enough
Adding "assert namespace is not None" causes 1800 failures!
Since there is no interoperability concern and namespaces make many otherwise good apis suck
gsnedders: Well clearly something is going wrong
I con't really look at it right now though
Fell free too make a patch or keep complaining at me untill I do
is looking at it right now
token.get("namespace", self.defaultNamespace) returns None
Ah, the TreeBuilder is being created with namespaceHTMLElements=False
Because it defaults to not namespacing them
We default to breaking the spec. Sounds great. :\
We default to sane behaviour for most python applications
But the default cn be changed if you are really bothered

silly question, but I've never thought about it before
is there anywhere in the spec that says _not_ to apply default styles to an element?
